description: From euhemerism +‎ -ize, ultimately from Latin Euhēmerus, from Ancient Greek Εὐήμερος (Euḗmeros), an ancient Greek Sicilian Skeptic who proposed most or all mythology derived from historical figures and natural events which received supernatural characteristics only through retelling.

verbs.description: euhemerize (third-person singular simple present euhemerizes, present participle euhemerizing, simple past and past participle euhemerized)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, derogatory) To invent a plausible but fanciful historical origin for something in order to explain away mythology and legends.
examples: He did but extend to the New Testament the Euhemerising principles which Eichhorn had applied to the Old.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) Synonym of deify: to actually create mythology and legends from ancient historical figures and events.
examples: Figures such as the Yellow Emperor and Yu the Great seem to have been euhemerized from prehistoric tribal leaders around the Yellow River.
